On a problem of Henning and Yeo about the transversal number of uniform linear systems whose 2-packing number is fixed

Abstract

A linear system is a pair (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) where â„’â„’\mathcal{L} is a family of subsets on a ground finite set Pğ‘ƒP such that |lâˆ©lâ€²|â‰¤1ğ‘™superscriptğ‘™â€²1|l\cap l^{\prime}|\leq 1, for every l,lâ€²âˆˆâ„’ğ‘™superscriptğ‘™â€²â„’l,l^{\prime}\in\mathcal{L}. If all elements of â„’â„’\mathcal{L} of a linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}), then the linear system is called rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system. The transversal number of a linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}), Ï„â€‹(P,â„’)ğœğ‘ƒâ„’\tau(P,\mathcal{L}), is the minimum cardinality of a subset P^âŠ†P^ğ‘ƒğ‘ƒ\hat{P}\subseteq P satisfying lâˆ©P^â‰ âˆ…ğ‘™^ğ‘ƒl\cap\hat{P}\neq\emptyset, for every lâˆˆâ„’ğ‘™â„’l\in\mathcal{L}. The 2-packing number of a linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}), Î½2â€‹(P,â„’)subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘ƒâ„’\nu_{2}(P,\mathcal{L}), is the maximum cardinality of a subset RâŠ†â„’ğ‘…â„’R\subseteq\mathcal{L} such that, any three elements of Rğ‘…R donâ€™t have a common point (are triplewise disjoint), that is, if three elements are chosen in Rğ‘…R, then they are not incidents in a common point.

For râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2, let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system. In â€M. A. Henning and A. Yeo: Hypergraphs with large transversal number, Discrete Math. 313 (2013), no. 8, 959â€“966.â€ Henning and Yeo state the following question: Is it true that if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system then Ï„â€‹(P,â„’)â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau(P,\mathcal{L})\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} holds for all râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2?. In this note, we give some results of rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems, whose 2-packing number is fixed, satisfying the inequality.

keywords:

1 Introduction

A linear system is a pair (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) where â„’â„’\mathcal{L} is a family of subsets on a ground finite set Pğ‘ƒP such that |lâˆ©lâ€²|â‰¤1ğ‘™superscriptğ‘™â€²1|l\cap l^{\prime}|\leq 1, for every pair of distinct subsets l,lâ€²âˆˆâ„’ğ‘™superscriptğ‘™â€²â„’l,l^{\prime}\in\mathcal{L}. The elements of Pğ‘ƒP and â„’â„’\mathcal{L} are called points and lines, respectively. An rğ‘Ÿr-line is a line containing exactly rğ‘Ÿr points. An rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system such that all lines of â„’â„’\mathcal{L} are rğ‘Ÿr-lines. In this context, a simple graph is a 2-uniform linear system. Throughout this paper, we will only consider linear systems of rank râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2.

Two points p,qâˆˆPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒp,q\in P are adjacent, if there is a line lâˆˆâ„’ğ‘™â„’l\in\mathcal{L} such that {p,q}âŠ†lğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™\{p,q\}\subseteq l.

Given a linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) and a point pâˆˆPğ‘ğ‘ƒp\in P, the linear system obtained from (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) by deleting point pğ‘p is the linear subsystem (Pâ€²,â„’â€²)superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscriptâ„’â€²(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) induced by â„’â€²={lâˆ–{p}:lâˆˆâ„’}superscriptâ„’â€²conditional-setğ‘™ğ‘ğ‘™â„’\mathcal{L}^{\prime}=\{l\setminus\{p\}:l\in\mathcal{L}\}. Finally, let (Pâ€²,â„’â€²)superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscriptâ„’â€²(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be two linear systems. We say that (Pâ€²,â„’â€²)superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscriptâ„’â€²(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) are isomorphic, (Pâ€²,â„’â€²)â‰ƒ(P,â„’)similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscriptâ„’â€²ğ‘ƒâ„’(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime})\simeq(P,\mathcal{L}), if after of deleting points of degree 1 or 0 from both, the systems (Pâ€²,â„’â€²)superscriptğ‘ƒâ€²superscriptâ„’â€²(P^{\prime},\mathcal{L}^{\prime}) and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) are isomorphic as hypergraphs, see [5].

Let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system. A subset TâŠ†Pğ‘‡ğ‘ƒT\subseteq P is a transversal of (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) (also called vertex cover or hitting set), if Tâˆ©lâ‰ âˆ…ğ‘‡ğ‘™T\cap l\neq\emptyset, for every line lâˆˆâ„’ğ‘™â„’l\in\mathcal{L}. The minimum cardinality of a transversal of a linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}), Ï„=Ï„â€‹(P,â„’)ğœğœğ‘ƒâ„’\tau=\tau(P,\mathcal{L}), is called transversal number of (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}). A subset RâŠ†â„’ğ‘…â„’R\subseteq\mathcal{L} is called a 2-packing of (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}), if any three elements are chosen in Rğ‘…R, then they are not incidents in a common point. The maximum cardinality of a 2-packing of (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}), Î½2=Î½2â€‹(P,â„’)subscriptğœˆ2subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘ƒâ„’\nu_{2}=\nu_{2}(P,\mathcal{L}), is called 2-packing number of (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}). This new parameter has been studied in some papers, see for example [3, 4, 5, 18, 19, 20].

In [5], was proved a relationship between the transversal and the 2-packing numbers

âŒˆÎ½2/2âŒ‰â‰¤Ï„â‰¤Î½2â€‹(Î½2âˆ’1)2.subscriptğœˆ22ğœsubscriptğœˆ2subscriptğœˆ212\lceil\nu_{2}/2\rceil\leq\tau\leq\frac{\nu_{2}(\nu_{2}-1)}{2}. (1)

Hence, the transversal number of any linear system is upper bounded for a quadratic function of their 2-packing number. For some linear systems the transversal number is bounded above by a linear function of their 2-packing number, see [3, 4, 5]. In [13], was proved, using probabilistic methods, the existence of kğ‘˜k-uniform linear systems (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) for infinitely many kğ‘˜kâ€™s and n=|P|ğ‘›ğ‘ƒn=|P| large enough, which transversal number is Ï„=nâˆ’oâ€‹(n)ğœğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘›\tau=n-o(n). This kğ‘˜k-uniform linear systems has 2-packing number upper bounded by 2â€‹nk2ğ‘›ğ‘˜\frac{2n}{k}.

There are also works where the transversal number of an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems (and in more general context) is bounded above by a function of their number points and lines, see for example [12, 14]. In [14], was stated the following question: Is it true that if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, for all râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2?. In [10], was proved the inequality when râˆˆ{2,3}ğ‘Ÿ23r\in\{2,3\}. In [12], was proved the inequality when Î”â‰¤2Î”2\Delta\leq 2 and there are only two families of rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems that achieve equality in the bound. On the other hand, in [12], was given a better upper bound for the transversal number in terms of the number of points and the number of lines, namely, it was proved if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Î”â‰¤2Î”2\Delta\leq 2 and râ‰¥3ğ‘Ÿ3r\geq 3 odd integer such that râ€‹(r2âˆ’3)â€‹Ï„â‰¤(râˆ’2)â€‹(r+1)â€‹n+(râˆ’1)2â€‹m+râˆ’1ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ‘Ÿ23ğœğ‘Ÿ2ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘›superscriptğ‘Ÿ12ğ‘šğ‘Ÿ1r(r^{2}-3)\tau\leq(r-2)(r+1)n+(r-1)^{2}m+r-1. Similar bounds was proven in the case when râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2 is even integer.

This paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, we present an infinite family of rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) which satisfy Ï„=|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau=\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, where râ‰¥3ğ‘Ÿ3r\geq 3 is an odd integer. This family of linar systems was defined in [3]. In Section 3, we prove that, if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Ï„=rğœğ‘Ÿ\tau=r, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. In Section 4, we prove, if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems with Î½2âˆˆ{2,3,4}subscriptğœˆ2234\nu_{2}\in\{2,3,4\}, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. Finally, in Section 5, we prove that, if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems with Î”=2Î”2\Delta=2, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}, satisfying the equality, if and only, if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an (Î½2âˆ’1)subscriptğœˆ21(\nu_{2}-1)-uniform linear systems with Î½2â‰¥2subscriptğœˆ22\nu_{2}\geq 2 being even integer. This results was obteined first in [12].

Theorem 2.2

If râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2 is an positive integer and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Î”â‰¥Î½2âˆ’1Î”subscriptğœˆ21\Delta\geq\nu_{2}-1, |â„’|â‰¥Î½2+Î”âˆ’2â„’subscriptğœˆ2Î”2|\mathcal{L}|\geq\nu_{2}+\Delta-2 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3, then Î½2âˆ’1â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1subscriptğœˆ21ğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\nu_{2}-1\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. Since |P|â‰¥Î”â€‹(râˆ’1)+1ğ‘ƒÎ”ğ‘Ÿ11|P|\geq\Delta(r-1)+1, we have

|P|+|â„’|r+1ğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1} â‰¥\displaystyle\geq Î”â€‹(râˆ’1)+1+Î½2+Î”âˆ’2r+1Î”ğ‘Ÿ11subscriptğœˆ2Î”2ğ‘Ÿ1\displaystyle\frac{\Delta(r-1)+1+\nu_{2}+\Delta-2}{r+1}
=\displaystyle= râ€‹Î”+Î½2âˆ’1r+1â‰¥(Î½2âˆ’1)â€‹(r+1)r+1ğ‘ŸÎ”subscriptğœˆ21ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğœˆ21ğ‘Ÿ1ğ‘Ÿ1\displaystyle\frac{r\Delta+\nu_{2}-1}{r+1}\geq\frac{(\nu_{2}-1)(r+1)}{r+1}
=\displaystyle= Î½2âˆ’1.subscriptğœˆ21\displaystyle\nu_{2}-1.

And the statement holds.\qed

Corollary 2.2

If râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2 is an positive integer and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Î”â‰¥Î½2Î”subscriptğœˆ2\Delta\geq\nu_{2}, |â„’|â‰¥Î½2+Î”âˆ’1â„’subscriptğœˆ2Î”1|\mathcal{L}|\geq\nu_{2}+\Delta-1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3, then Î½2â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\nu_{2}\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. The proof of this corollary is analogous to the proof of Theorem 2.2.\qed

Lemma 3.3

Let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system, with râ‰¥3ğ‘Ÿ3r\geq 3 be an odd integer. If Ï„=rğœğ‘Ÿ\tau=r, then Î½2=r+1subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘Ÿ1\nu_{2}=r+1.

Now, letâ€™s deal the case when rğ‘Ÿr is an even integer. Corollary 3.2

Hence, if Ï„>r+22ğœğ‘Ÿ22\tau>\frac{r+2}{2} then Î½2â‰¤rsubscriptğœˆ2ğ‘Ÿ\nu_{2}\leq r and râ‰¥4ğ‘Ÿ4r\geq 4 an even integer.

Lemma 3.5

Let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an intersecting rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system, with râ‰¥4ğ‘Ÿ4r\geq 4 be an even integer. If Ï„=rğœğ‘Ÿ\tau=r, then Î½2=rsubscriptğœˆ2ğ‘Ÿ\nu_{2}=r.

Let p,qâˆˆPğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ƒp,q\in P be two points such that dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(p)=Î”ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘Î”deg(p)=\Delta and Î”â€²=dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(q)=maxâ¡{dâ€‹eâ€‹gâ€‹(x):xâˆˆPâˆ–{p}}superscriptÎ”â€²ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘:ğ‘‘ğ‘’ğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘\Delta^{\prime}=deg(q)=\max\{deg(x):x\in P\setminus\{p\}\}. Corollary 3.3

Let râ‰¥4ğ‘Ÿ4r\geq 4 be an even integer. If (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Ï„=rğœğ‘Ÿ\tau=r, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. By Lemma 3.1 and Lemma 3.5 follows that Î”=Î½2=rÎ”subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘Ÿ\Delta=\nu_{2}=r. Hence, by Corollary 2.2 we have Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.\qed

By Corollary 3.3 and Corollary 3.1, we have

Theorem 3.2

Let râ‰¥3ğ‘Ÿ3r\geq 3 be an integer. If (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is an intersecting rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Ï„=rğœğ‘Ÿ\tau=r, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

A finite projective plane, or merely projective plane, is an intersecting linear system satisfying:

  • 1.

    any pair of points have a common line,

  • 2.

    any pair of lines have a common point, and

  • 3.

    there exist four points in general position (there are not three collinear points).

It is well known, if (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is a projective plane, there exists a number qâˆˆâ„•ğ‘â„•q\in\mathbb{N}, called order of projective plane, such that every point (line, respectively) of (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is incident to exactly q+1ğ‘1q+1 lines (points, respectively), and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) contains exactly q2+q+1superscriptğ‘2ğ‘1q^{2}+q+1 points (lines, respectively). Also, it is well known that projective planes of order qğ‘q, denoted by Î qsubscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi_{q}, exist when qğ‘q is a power prime. For more information about the existence and the unicity of projective planes see, for instance, [7, 8].

In relation to the transversal number of projective planes, it is well known that every line in Î qsubscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi_{q} is a minimum transversal, then Ï„â€‹(Î q)=q+1ğœsubscriptÎ ğ‘ğ‘1\tau(\Pi_{q})=q+1. On the other hand, related to the 2-packing number of a projective planes, since projective planes are dual systems, this parameter coincides with the cardinality of an oval, which is the maximum number of points in general position (no three of them collinear), and it is equal to q+1ğ‘1q+1 when qğ‘q is odd integer, and it is equal to q+2ğ‘2q+2 when qğ‘q is even integer (see for example [8]).

Consequently, for projective planes Î qsubscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi_{q} of odd order qğ‘q we have that Ï„â€‹(Î q)=Î½2â€‹(Î q)=q+1ğœsubscriptÎ ğ‘subscriptğœˆ2subscriptÎ ğ‘ğ‘1\tau(\Pi_{q})=\nu_{2}(\Pi_{q})=q+1. On the other hand, for projective planes Î qsubscriptÎ ğ‘\Pi_{q} of even order qğ‘q we have that Ï„â€‹(Î q)=Î½2â€‹(Î q)âˆ’1=qğœsubscriptÎ ğ‘subscriptğœˆ2subscriptÎ ğ‘1ğ‘\tau(\Pi_{q})=\nu_{2}(\Pi_{q})-1=q, see [5].

Corollary 3.4

Let qğ‘q be a prime power, and let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an (q+1)ğ‘1(q+1)-uniform linear system such that (P,â„’)â‰ƒÎ qsimilar-to-or-equalsğ‘ƒâ„’subscriptÎ ğ‘(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\Pi_{q}, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|q+2ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘2\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{q+2}.

Proof. The proof is a simple consequence of Theorem 2.2 and Corollary 2.2, since Î”=q+1Î”ğ‘1\Delta=q+1 and Î½2=q+2subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘2\nu_{2}=q+2, if qğ‘q is an even integer, and Î½2=q+1subscriptğœˆ2ğ‘1\nu_{2}=q+1, if qğ‘q is odd integer.

4 rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear systems with Î½2âˆˆ{2,3,4}subscriptğœˆ2234\nu_{2}\in\{2,3,4\}

Let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Î½2âˆˆ{2,3}subscriptğœˆ223\nu_{2}\in\{2,3\}. It is not difficult to prove (see [5]) that, Î½2=2subscriptğœˆ22\nu_{2}=2, if and only if, Ï„=1ğœ1\tau=1. As |P|=Î”â€‹(râˆ’1)+1ğ‘ƒÎ”ğ‘Ÿ11|P|=\Delta(r-1)+1 and |â„’|=Î”â„’Î”|\mathcal{L}|=\Delta, then Ï„<|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau<\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. On the other hand, if Î½2=3subscriptğœˆ23\nu_{2}=3, then Ï„=2ğœ2\tau=2, see [5]. As |P|â‰¥Î”â€‹(râˆ’1)+1ğ‘ƒÎ”ğ‘Ÿ11|P|\geq\Delta(r-1)+1 and |â„’|=Î”+1â„’Î”1|\mathcal{L}|=\Delta+1, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

The main result of this section states the following:

Theorem 4.1

Let râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2 be an integer and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with |â„’|>Î½2â„’subscriptğœˆ2|\mathcal{L}|>\nu_{2}. If Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

To proove the Theorem 4.1, we assume Î”â‰¤4Î”4\Delta\leq 4, since

Lemma 4.1

[5] Any linear system (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) with Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4 and Î”â‰¥5Î”5\Delta\geq 5 satisfies Ï„â‰¤Î½2âˆ’1ğœsubscriptğœˆ21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

And by Theorem 2.2, we have Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Lemma 4.2

[5] Let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be a linear system with Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4 and Î”=3Î”3\Delta=3. If (P,â„’)â‰ƒğ’3,4similar-to-or-equalsğ‘ƒâ„’subscriptğ’34(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\mathcal{C}_{3,4}, then Ï„=Î½2ğœsubscriptğœˆ2\tau=\nu_{2}, otherwise Ï„â‰¤Î½2âˆ’1ğœsubscriptğœˆ21\tau\leq\nu_{2}-1.

Corollary 4.1

Let râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2 be an integer and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system. If Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4 and Î”=3Î”3\Delta=3, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. And, the equality holds, if and only if, (P,â„’)=ğ’3,4ğ‘ƒâ„’subscriptğ’34(P,\mathcal{L})=\mathcal{C}_{3,4}.

Proof. Let (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system with Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4 and Î”=3Î”3\Delta=3 such that (P,â„’)â‰ƒÌ¸ğ’3,4not-similar-to-or-equalsğ‘ƒâ„’subscriptğ’34(P,\mathcal{L})\not\simeq\mathcal{C}_{3,4}. By Theorem 2.2 and Lemma 4.2, we have Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. On the other hand, if (P,â„’)â‰ƒğ’3,4similar-to-or-equalsğ‘ƒâ„’subscriptğ’34(P,\mathcal{L})\simeq\mathcal{C}_{3,4} then |P|=8+8â€‹kğ‘ƒ88ğ‘˜|P|=8+8k and |â„’|=8â„’8|\mathcal{L}|=8, where k+3=rğ‘˜3ğ‘Ÿk+3=r and kâ‰¥0ğ‘˜0k\geq 0. Hence

|P|+|â„’|r+1=8â€‹(k+2)k+4â‰¥164=4=Ï„.ğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ18ğ‘˜2ğ‘˜41644ğœ\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}=\frac{8(k+2)}{k+4}\geq\frac{16}{4}=4=\tau.

Hence, Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}. The equality holds, if and only if, k=0ğ‘˜0k=0, that is, if and only if, (P,â„’)=ğ’3,4ğ‘ƒâ„’subscriptğ’34(P,\mathcal{L})=\mathcal{C}_{3,4}\qed

Lemma 4.3

[5] If (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) is a linear system with Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4 and Î”=4Î”4\Delta=4, then Ï„=Î½2ğœsubscriptğœˆ2\tau=\nu_{2}.

Corollary 4.2

Let râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2 be an integer and (P,â„’)ğ‘ƒâ„’(P,\mathcal{L}) be an rğ‘Ÿr-uniform linear system. If Î½2=4subscriptğœˆ24\nu_{2}=4 and Î”=4Î”4\Delta=4, then Ï„â‰¤|P|+|â„’|r+1ğœğ‘ƒâ„’ğ‘Ÿ1\tau\leq\displaystyle\frac{|P|+|\mathcal{L}|}{r+1}.

Proof. The proof is a direct consequence of Corollary 2.2 and Lemma 4.3. \qed

Corollary 5.1

and the statement holds.\qed
